1976

Winner

Jean-Michel Jarre - Oxygene

One of the few artists I got into when I was young (not in 1976, obviously) and before I was gripped by the majesty of rock (and the mystery of roll) was J-MJ. I like pretty much all his stuff and always have. Oxygene was probably my favourite of his, and â€œOxygene 4â€ was used on the TV in the 70s and 80s all over the place. Still listen to this now and still love it.

Top tracks: The whole thing, really, but if you have to pick one out, itâ€™s â€œOxygene 4â€

1975

Led Zeppelin - Physical Graffitti

1974

Honourable mention

Deep Purple - Burn

Deep Purple have had as many lineup changes as any band you can mention, and are still going today. In fact, their 2017 album Infinite is on the longlist for that year, though I need more time with it to see if it makes the shortlist. Burn, however, was â€œthe first Deep Purple album to feature then-unknown David Coverdale on vocalsâ€, and doesnâ€™t it just? Blackmore is on fire, Coverdale and Glenn Hughes smash the vocals out of the park, and mainstays Lord and Paice do what they do best. I hadnâ€™t properly consumed this album until recently, only really being familiar with the title track, but it is indeed a cracker. Top track: â€œBurnâ€, natch.

Winner

Queen - Sheer Heart Attack

Back to the mixed bag of Queen then, to round this thing out. This was in fact their second album of 1974, following the release of Queen II earlier on, and it is an entirely different gunnysack of weaselfish than the bandâ€™s first two albums which were heavily 70s-prog influenced. This for me was where they started to really find their stride and start writing true Queen material, and while there are occasional oddities (â€œBring Back That Leroy Brownâ€, anyone?) itâ€™s otherwise solid and home to not only classics like â€œKiller Queenâ€, â€œBrighton Rockâ€ and â€œStone Cold Crazyâ€, but my favourite Queen song of all time, â€œNow Iâ€™m Hereâ€.

Not perfect, but bloody good.
